docs.lead_paragraph: Because its record-keeping is poor, Aetna has been paying millions of dollars in medical claims for people whose benefits have expired, the company's chief executive told investors yesterday. Aetna, which lost $36.6 million from operations in the first quarter, is trying to fix the problem quickly, the chief executive, John W. Rowe, said. Mr. Rowe said a new system might be in place in 40 days. The company is struggling to control medical costs as it relaxes some restrictions on care under pressure from patients and physicians who have complained that Aetna pays claims slowly and requires too much paperwork. Aetna, which has about 18.3 million customers, is dropping about 10 percent of its unprofitable clients this year to increase profit.

headline.main: AETNA CHIEF SAYS RECORD-KEEPING LAPSES COST MILLIONS

docs.abstract: Aetna chief executive John W Rowe says that poor record-keeping has caused company to pay out millions of dollars in medical claims for people whose benefits have expired; vows to fix problem (S)
docs.snippet: Because its record-keeping is poor, Aetna has been paying millions of dollars in medical claims for people whose benefits have expired, the company's chief executive told investors yesterday. Aetna, which lost $36.6 million from operations in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost nothing about the new tax law is irreversible. Even before President Bush signed it this morning with great fanfare at a White House ceremony, the politicians were talking about how to revise it. So this law -- Mr. Bush's top legislative priority -- will not necessarily lead to the kind of permanent change that would occur if Congress approved some of his other big policy proposals, like converting a part of Social Security into private savings accounts or requiring retirees on Medicare to shop for health insurance in the private market or installing a missile defense system.
docs.abstract: News analysis of efforts getting under way on Capitol Hill to revise tax law just signed by Pres Bush; Republicans want to speed up tax rate reductions and give new tax breaks to businesses; Democrats, who now control Senate, want to block some of cuts in new law before they take effect (M)
